subject: September Morn
event: Can it really be September? What the hell happened to August? Oh, I remember... a week of meetings in LA, a week at worldcon, Bubonicon, house guests and visitors, business meetings... damn... I wanted to blog about worldcon and the Hugo Awards and the Alfies and an EPIC Hugo Losers Party and the presidential election and HIGH STAKES and a very special week we have planned at the Jean Cocteau and lots of other stuff, and maybe I still will in the days to come, but right at the moment I am too tired. Some of that stuff already seems like ages ago. And I have lots to catch up on. But it's been a while, so I thought I should at least say hi, and wave, and let everyone know that I'm still here, back at the old homestead and back at work. Also, I wanted to give a shout out to Ogre Jenni, who, alas, has left the Jean Cocteau and Fevre River to accept a full-time teaching job. That's great news for Jenni, and all the kids that she will be teaching in the years to come, but sad news for us. Jenni was terrific, a wonderful member of our crew here, and we miss her lots already. At least she is still in town, so we will get to see her socially from time to time. Fly high, Higginbotham!

comments.article: Enjoyed the Wild Cards panel and signing and really enjoyed the Hugo Loser's Party.  I went to a few movies at the Midland back in the 70's and it was a great place to hold the party.  Thanks for acknowledging the people that you awarded Alfies to.
comments.subject: WorldCon

comments.article:
Just got back home from our Higginbotham family reunion! I wonder if there's any (distant) relation hah.

Anyway, welcome home George. Glad to hear you had a good time away.
comments.subject: Higginbotham!

comments.article:
Yesterday, while going for a walk with my 4 kids, we noticed that the leaves started to change color and that the air simply smells like autumn. I love fall, but well, summer passed by so fast.
I am always happy too read your blog entries and yes, I missed them and so I am happy about this short "hello" :) I hope that you are sleeping well and wish you a wionderful start into the weekend.
Your fan Melanie (The writing mombie :) ) from Germany.
comments.subject: Time passes by so fast, that's true....

comments.article:
Hey George!

Thanks for the check-in. I was just thinking a couple of days ago that I missed hearing from you. I hope KC treated you well. It's my original hometown, and I've always loved hearing your positive feelings toward the place. Hope they're still intact! So please, get some rest and then let us hear all about it.

Well wishes to Orge Jenni in her new endeavor. I, for one, will miss her funny posts, but I'm glad to hear this is a good move for her. Bon chance!!
comments.subject: Welcome home!

comments.article: glad to see your blogs again george!Apparently this is you longest you have not posted a blog since 2007!

George,

I had a quick 30 second chat with you at Bubonicon without anyone else present really (I had asked you about being mobbed at Comic Con and you gave me a funny anecdote), and it felt nice to be able to have a normal interaction without the pressures of a large crowd or the media. We appreciate your yearly presence and hope you enjoy toned-down feel our quirky little con. It's always nice to attend your readings!

- Bo King
comments.subject: Bubonicon!

comments.article:
Hope you are doing well! What is your favorite part of the Fall season? I'd have to say mine is Holloween, though it's more than a month away.

Take care!
comments.subject: Cheers!

comments.article: September is the best time of the year.  Its Autumn (fall) its harvest time, the colours on the leaves start to change you can smell the seasonal change in the air and the nights begin to get darker earlier :D its a good time for staying indoors getting cozy reading or writing.x
comments.subject: September

comments.article:
Welcome home, Mr. Martin... and thanks for the earworm. :)

♫ September morning still can make me feel that way... ♫
comments.subject: ♪ Stay for just a while... ♪

comments.article: Welcome back, George, and we'll settle for an account, even a brief one, of the "epic" Hugo Losers Party! :)
comments.subject: Hugo Losers

comments.article: This is probably not the best forum to ask for advice about dealing with anxiety and depression.  As both a physician and as someone with a history of depression, I would strongly advise you to see a mental health professional.  I would suggest starting with a psychiatrist (who is someone with an MD and can prescribe medications) and then asking for a referral to an appropriate psychologist (who is usually a PhD and who probably specializes in treating a small subset of mental health issues) for therapy.  You often have to try several different avenues of treatment until you find the one that works for you, so try not to be too disappointed if your first attempt at treatment doesn't seem to help.
comments.subject: RE: rest easy

comments.article:
It has been so damn humid in the northeast. Bring on autumn with the 50 degree nights, football on Sundays, hiking without being bitten by mosquitos, overdosing on artificial pumpkin flavoring...

I always prefer the cold over the heat. My only complaint when it comes to the cold--this is completely genuine too-- is when it's gusty winds and freezing temperatures. So yes, I too agonize about the experience of the winds of winter.
comments.subject: Screw August

comments.article:
Yeah, same thing here, August was a relentless flurry of events.

I remembered today I have short story to finish, I knew I hammered most of it and let it rest a day or two while I go on about other business. Today I saw it was last written on 29th July and "day or two" was somehow transformed to a month.

Here's to calm and peaceful September.
comments.subject: Disappearing August

comments.article: Oh man, I've been looking forward to this month for sometime. On top of the beginning of pro and college football, we'll also have the first debate which should be explosive, and then the premiere of Westworld (which is actually in October but who's counting?). I can't imagine you're going to miss that one George -- HBO + dark speculative fiction + Jonathan Nolan + unbelievable cast + Ramin Djwadi = heaven. Anyway, look forward to your posts.

Saw this interesting article on the Lit Hub.. thought you would appreciate. Glad to see you're back, GRRM!
http://lithub.com/how-a-self-published-writer-of-gay-erotica-beat-sci-fis-sad-puppiesat-their-own-game/
comments.subject: Hugo

comments.article: I'm so glad September is here! It's been such a hot humid summer in Ontario. Looking forward to fall with the colors, pumpkin everything and Halloween just around the corner. Hope you have a happy and productive one :)
comments.subject: September yay!

comments.article: August went by in the blink of an eye here as well but contained one momentous event that I owe you many thanks for. I became engaged to someone I met (via westeros.org, no less) because of our shared interest in ASoIaF. Now I know we're not the first people brought together over the internet by a shared interest, nor the first by ASoIaF, and not even the first by ASoIaF who are from different sides of the Atlantic, but it feels like a miracle to me and we are very grateful to you for providing the spark that gave us this opportunity. So thanks George! Enjoy your September and many good wishes to Jenni in her new career!
comments.subject: August

comments.article:
What a coincidence! I manage the social for a gardening website and used that exact September quote this morning as well! (each day of the year gets a quote and a beautiful image)

Glad to see you back and can't wait to hear about your adventures!

Hi George,
I hope to see you in my country again.

Bye and good job.
comments.subject: Italy

comments.article:
We chatted in the hallway at WorldCon about how much improvement there was in nominations for 2016. I thought it had doubled, but you didn't think it had gone up that much. Looking at the actual numbers, Novel, Novella, and Short Story more than doubled. Novelette almost doubled (up 92%).

The truth is, fans nominated their hearts out this year, but it didn't make any difference. In fact, we lost ground because the slates also doubled their numbers, and the mathematics that govern the old voting system would have required fan nominations go up by a factor of 4 just to stay even. If the slates had played their cards right, they could have swept all but two categories and filled the rest with trash. Imagine a ceremony where "No Award" was given in all but two categories! Only the stupidity of the people running the slates saved us. By nominating some worthwhile works and some works by people who declined the nomination, they left us enough breathing room to actually have an awards ceremony worthy of the name.

We can't count on the slates to continue to be stupid, nor can we expect fans to increase nominations by a further factor of 10 or more, which is what it would take to defeat the slates through sheer weight of numbers (assuming the slates cannot increase their numbers). EPH has its problems, but it will forever protect us from the threat of an awards ceremony with no awards.

It was good to meet you in person, and I appreciated your kind words about Rocket Stack Rank. Even with EPH the system depends on strong fan participation, and we still see an important role for promoting short fiction.
comments.subject: Nomination Improvements from 2015 to 2016

comments.article:
I have seen the numbers too, but I draw different conclusions from them than you do. However, I prefer not to argue that here, in the comments section. If I find the time and energy, I will have a separate post about it and we can hash it out here.

In general, I continue to have deep misgivings about the various proposals to reform the Hugo voting rules. EPH and 5/6 are now official, I suppose, and may have some beneficial effects next year. That remains to be seen. Neither one is going to a magic bullet, however, and EPH in particular troubles me, though I confess I have no better answer.

As for three stage voting, with the blackball round, that one really troubles me, and I hope it is not ratified. That's a cure that, if not worse than the disease, is at least equally bad.

In My Not So Humble Opinion, at least.

In any case... I do think you do good work with Rocket Stack Rank. Keep it up.
comments.subject: Re: Nomination Improvements from 2015 to 2016

comments.article:
Good to hear you enjoyed the Con and KC. Epic parties sound perfect!! Is there any chance you will attend "Con of Thrones" in Nashville next June/July?? Attending my 1st Con there next year, how perfect to see the man who wrote my favorite saga.

Rest Well!!
comments.subject: Always good to hear your Hi's and thought's!!

comments.article: Afraid not.  I am not taking on any new cons until I finish WINDS... just worldcons (of course) and appearances I have already committed to (often years ago) like Tucson and Mexico.
comments.subject: ARe: Always good to hear your Hi's and thought's!!

comments.article: Hope you had a great time George.

I hope you do a blog on the Alfies and Hugo Losers party when you get settled back in and find the time. I always look forward to those blogs every year. I never get to go to the cons myself so it's sort of my way of living it and hearing about it. Those parties always seem like a good time. Last years blog about the Alfies was REALLY cool so I hope to hear an update about all the fun you had with that.

Good for Ogre Jenni on her teaching job, too. That's definitely good news. You'll have to get another minion to update us about the Jean Cocteau though.

Anyway, good to see you back. Looking forward to hearing how the awards went.
